publisher.publisher-name: Pacific Ancient and Modern Language Association

title-group.article-title: Reconsidering Reparation: Mary Elizabeth Braddon's "Lady Audley's Secret" and Critical Reading Practices

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2008 Pacific Ancient and Modern Language Association

ref.mixed-citation: Patrick Brantflinger explains that the sensation novel is a "unique mixture of contempo- rary domestic realism with elements of the Gothic romance, the Newgate novel of criminal 'low life/ and the 'silver fork' novel of scandalous and sometimes criminal 'high life'" (1).
"Melanie Klein and the Difference Affect Makes," Sedgwick revisits her theorization of paranoid/schizoid reading structures and reparative (depressive) reading (625-42).
Brantflinger uses the term "amateur-detective hero" in "What's So 'Sensational' about the 'Sensation' Novel?" (14).

Sedgwick states that "the paranoid trust in exposure seemingly depends, in addition, on an infinite reservoir of naivete in those who make up the audience for these unveilings" (Touch- ing Feeling 141).

Melanie Klein's theory, Britzman writes in her essay "Theory Kindergarten": "She [Klein] argues that the desire to know does not reside in render- ing the visible as intelligible but, instead, curiosity's preoccupation is with trying to make sense of the invisible, with what the baby cannot see. It is the empty space within, that the curiosity aims to fill" (133).
she explains that reparation is characterized by a "glue of surplus beauty, surplus stylistic investment (Touch- ing 150).
Brantflinger writes that, according to contemporaneous critics, these news reports would "virtually write [the] fiction for [the sensation novelist]" (10).
Thackeray 748
T.S. Eliot's "Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock,"

Donne: "I have heard the mermaids singing, each to each. / I do not think that they will sing to me. /I have seen riding seaward on the waves /Combing the white hair of the waves blown back/ When the wind blows the water white and black. / We have lingered in the chambers of the sea / By sea-girls wreathed with seaweed red and brown / Till human voices wake us, and we drown" (123-30).
Richard Howard explains the distinction that "pleasure is a state, of course, bliss {jouissance) an action, and both of them, in our culture, are held to be unspeakable, beyond words" (vi).

Bruce Fink explains that phallic jouissance is differentiated from feminine jouissance insofar as it is "the jouissance that fails us, that disappoints us. It is susceptible to failure, and fundamentally misses our partner" ("Knowledge and Jouissance" 37).
Sontag writes in Against Interpretation: "What is important now is to recover our senses. We must learn to see more, to hear more, to feel more" (14).

Braddon, Mary Elizabeth. Lady Audley's Secret. 1862. Oxford: Oxford UP, 1998.

Carr, Brian. "Paranoid Interpretation, Desire's Nonobject, and Nella Larsen's Passing." PMLA 119.2 (2003): 282-295.

Donne, John. "Song." Selected Poetry. Ed. John Carey. Oxford: Oxford UP, 1996. 82-83.

Evans, Dylan. An Introductory Dictionary to Lacanian Psychoanalysis. New York: Routledge, 1997.
Fink, Bruce. "Knowledge and Jouissance." Reading Seminar XX: Lacan's Major Work on Love, Knowledge, and Feminine Sexuality. Eds. Suzanne Barnard and Bruce Fink. New York: SUNY UP, 2002. 21-45.
Howard, Richard. Preface. The Pleasure of the Text. By Roland Barthes. New York: Hill and Wang, 1975. i-vi.

Kelleher, Paul. "If Love Were All: Reading Sedgwick Sentimentally." Regard- ing Sedgwick: Essays on Queer Culture and Critical Theory. Ed. Stephen M. Bar- ber and David L. Clark. New York: Routledge, 2002.143-162.
Lacan, Jacques. On Feminine Sexuality, The Limits of Love and Knowledge: The Seminar of Jacques Lacan, Book XX, Encore. 1975. Ed. Jacques-Alain Miller. Trans. Bruce Fink. New York: Norton, 1998.
Mansel, Henry. "Sensation Novels." Quarterly Review 113 (1863): 501.
Miller, D.A. The Novel and the Police. Berkeley: U of California P, 1988.
Ricoeur, Paul. Freud and Philosophy: An Essay on Interpretation. Trans. Denis Sav- age. New Haven: Yale UP, 1970.
Sedgwick, Eve Kosofsky. "Melanie Klein and the Difference Affect Makes." South Atlantic Quarterly 106.3 (2007): 625-642.
_. "Paranoid Reading and Reparative Reading; or, You're So Paranoid, You Probably Think This Introduction Is about You." Novel Gazing: Queer Readings in Fiction. Durham: Duke UP, 1997.1-37.
_. Touching Feeling: Affect, Pedagogy, Performativity. Durham: Duke UP, 2003.
Sontag, Susan. Against Interpretation and Other Essays. New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1966.
Thackeray, William Makepeace. Vanity Fair. 1848. London: Penguin, 2001.
Tillotson, Kathleen. "Introduction: The Lighter Reading of the Eighteen-Six- ties." The Woman in White. By Wilkie Collins. Boston: Houghton, 1969. ix- xx vi.
